posts.author: RulesMaster
posts.content:
I've been thinking about multiclass lately and wanted to get everyone's opinions.

Quick question about multiclass that came up in our game last night.

What are the best multiclass combinations that synergize well with multiclass? I'm particularly interested in optimizing for combat effectiveness.

What do you all think? Has anyone else had similar questions about multiclass?

posts.author: RogueReroll
posts.content:
When DMing, I like to use Cleric/Cleric as a way to create interesting challenges for my players.

The way I understand the rules for Cleric/Cleric, it should work like this: when you take the action, you need to roll ability checks to determine the outcome.

How do other DMs balance encounters that involve Cleric/Cleric? I find it either makes combats too easy or too difficult.

posts.author: CriticalMiss
posts.content:
We had a hilarious situation where our Bard tried to use multiclass to negotiate with a dragon. It went exactly as you'd expect!

In our last session, we encountered a Basilisk and tried to use multiclass to gain an advantage, but it didn't work out as planned.

The way I understand the rules for multiclass, it should work like this: when you take the action, you need to roll ability checks to determine the outcome.

I actually disagree with some of the previous comments about multiclass. Based on my experience, it works differently.

posts.author: SorcerousSally
posts.content:
Looking at page 127 of the Player's Handbook, it states that Cleric/Cleric functions based on your proficiency bonus and ability modifiers.

When DMing, I like to use Cleric/Cleric as a way to create interesting challenges for my players.

We had a hilarious situation where our Bard tried to use Cleric/Cleric to negotiate with a dragon. It went exactly as you'd expect!

In my campaign, we had a situation with Cleric/Cleric that played out really well. The player used it creatively to overcome a challenge I didn't expect them to solve.
